content: God need not examine a man further: Elihu said this to disagree with Job's wish for God to quickly announce a time of judgment (21:19; 24:1). Elihu believed that God already understood all people perfectly without needing to set up a special court or investigation.

title: Job 34:24
content:
• God knows everything without needing to ask anyone (34:25).

  • sets up others in their place: Daniel 2:21; 5:28–30.

title: Job 34:26
content: When God shows justice openly, it causes evil people to have proper fear (Deuteronomy 21:21; 1 Timothy 5:20). This leads to public joy among people in a right relationship with God (compare Exodus 14:30–31).

title: Job 34:31
content: Suppose someone says: Elihu posed the indirect question, "Job, why won't you admit it?"

title: Job 34:36
content: tried to the utmost: Zophar also said that Job should have suffered worse punishment than he did (11:6).

title: Job 35:4–8
content:
Elihu tried to answer his own question (35:2).

But his response did not add anything new compared to:

  • Zophar (11:8–9).

  • Eliphaz (22:12).

  • Bildad (25:5–6).

  • Job (9:8–10).

Elihu did not realize that all sin offends God (Genesis 39:9; Matthew 25:41–46; compare Proverbs 19:17).

title: Job 35:15–16
content: Elihu echoed Job's words but then disagreed with them (9:24; 12:6–10; 21:7–15, 17).

title: Job 35:16
content: Elihu echoed his earlier accusation (34:35). Later, God would agree (38:2).

title: Job 36:4
content: one who is perfect in knowledge is with you: Elihu probably was claiming to be sincere or that his logic had no flaw.

title: Job 36:7
content: The Bible teaches that God always watches over the righteous (2 Chronicles 16:9; Psalms 33:18; 34:15; 1 Peter 3:12). This idea addresses Job's frustration about God's surveillance (Job 7:17–21).

title: Job 36:11
content: If they obey and serve Him, then they end their days in prosperity: This is a true biblical principle of dedication to God (repentance) (see 11:13–19; 22:21–25; Deuteronomy 4:30; Jeremiah 7:23; 26:13).

title: Job 36:12
content: die without knowledge: See also 4:21; Proverbs 5:23; 10:21.

title: Job 36:31
content: The Hebrew yadin typically means he judges or he governs. But some commentators propose an alternate reading, yazun (meaning "he nourishes"). This aligns with the theme of God's provision (Job 38:26; Psalms 65:9–13; 104:13–15, 27–28). The more common meaning of yadin is “judge,” which would mean that God does all things to bless his people and judge his enemies (Job 37:11–13; 38:22–23; see Genesis 6:17; 19:24; Exodus 9:23–25; Joshua 10:11–14; 1 Samuel 12:18).

title: Job 37:2
content: The Old Testament often links thunder to God's voice (36:29, 33; 37:5; 38:1; Exodus 19:16–19; Psalm 104:7).

title: Job 37:7
content: He seals up the hand of every man … know His work: The end of the farming season gives people time to think about God's control over everything.

title: Job 37:13
content: God's actions can have multiple purposes. For example, storms can both destroy enemies and bring victory to God's people (Joshua 10; Judges 4; 1 Samuel 7:10–11; Psalms 18:7–15; 105:32–33).

title: Job 37:17
content: The hot south wind made it very hot and uncomfortable.

title: Job 37:20
content: Should He be told that I want to speak? Would a man ask to be swallowed up?: Contesting God's judgment might lead to severe punishment, even death (see 13:14).

title: Job 37:22
content: Out of the north (Hebrew from Zaphon): In the literature of the ancient city of Ugarit, Zaphon was the northern mountain home of the false god "Baal." Here, it symbolically refers to the height of God's home in the heavens (see Isaiah 14:13–14).

title: Job 37:23
content:
• The Almighty is beyond our reach: Compare 11:7; 26:14; Romans 11:33; 1 Timothy 6:16.

  • His justice and great righteousness: Compare Job 9:4, 19; 12:13; Psalms 62:11; 66:3; 93:1; 99:4.

title: Job 38:1–3
content: the LORD answered Job out of the whirlwind: The Old Testament often links storms with God's presence (2 Kings 2:1, 11; Ezekiel 1:4; Nahum 1:3). Job finally had the chance to speak with God (Job 13:22–23).

title: Job 38:1–40.5
content: God challenges Job. Job admits he cannot judge the moral world. God shows Job's ignorance of the natural world's elements related to the realm of heaven, weather, animals, and birds (38:4–21; 22–38; 39–39:30).

title: Job 38:1–42.6
content: Then the LORD answered Job: In this last part, the LORD challenges Job's strong self-defense by showing his works. This reminds Job of God's supreme greatness.

title: Job 38:2
content: obscures My counsel: God’s accusation is similar to a charge made by Eliphaz and Elihu (15:2; 34:35; 35:16). Job eventually admitted his guilt (42:3).

title: Job 38:7
content: God describes the morning stars as if they are people, similar to the description of angels (1:6; 2:1).

title: Job 38:10–11
content: set in place its bars and doors: God describes the sea as a dangerous creature that is kept under control.

title: Job 38:14
content: stand out like the folds of a garment: The rising sun highlights the colors, shapes, and textures of objects.

title: Job 38:21
content: you were already born: Compare with Proverbs 8:25. This sarcasm is similar to Eliphaz's words in Job 15:7.

title: Job 38:22–23
content: God stores up snow and hail, like the deep seas and winds (Psalms 33:7; 135:7; Jeremiah 10:13; 51:16). God uses these elements as weapons through storms he sends on the day of war and battle (Job 36:32; Isaiah 30:30; Ezekiel 13:11–13; Revelation 16:21; for example, Joshua 10:11; Judges 5:20–21; 1 Samuel 7:10.

title: Job 38:24–27
content:
• The east wind blows from the desert, drying up crops and seas (Genesis 41:6, 23, 27; Jeremiah 4:11; Jonah 4:8; Exodus 14:21; Isaiah 11:15). It is not like the heavy rain that causes floods.

  • Helpful rain quenches a barren land (Psalms 104:10–11; 107:35; Isaiah 35:7; 58:11). This contrasts with both hot winds and flooding rains (Job 38:24, 25).

title: Job 38:36
content: heart … mind: These words can also mean "ibis" and "rooster." The Egyptians believed the ibis bird knew about the Nile's flooding, the most important event in Egypt. Israel’s rabbis (religious teachers with authority) believed the rooster bird could predict rain or its distinctive sound (crowing) marked day and night. The question would then be Who taught the ibis and the rooster? See also Psalm 51:6; Proverbs 2:6; James 1:5, 17.

title: Job 39:5–7
content: the wild donkey … scorns the tumult of the city: This is the first example in a series of animals that think little of other animals not their equal (compare 39:18, 22; 41:29). These images show how God scorns the opposition of a person like Job (see Psalm 2:4).

title: Job 39:9–12
content: The wild ox now no longer exists and was already rare by Moses's time. It was the strongest land animal in early Canaan. They never tamed this Old Testament symbol of strength (Numbers 23:22; 24:8; Deuteronomy 33:17; Psalms 29:6; 92:10; compare Genesis 1:28; 9:2; Psalm 8:5–6).

title: Job 39:13–18
content: In the ancient Near East, people believed the ostrich was a bird that God had not given wisdom.

title: Job 39:14–16
content:
The ostrich symbolizes neglect for her young because she (Lamentations 4:3):

  1. Leaves her eggs on the ground.

  2. Seems to abandon her eggs when a predator comes near. She is probably trying to distract the predator from the nest.

  3. Lays her eggs with other female ostrich in a shared nest, so many eggs are not her own.

title: Job 39:18
content: laughs at the horse and its rider: See 39:7, 22; 41:29.

title: Job 39:24
content: They blew the ram's horn in battle to signal the attack (Joshua 6:4–6).

title: Job 39:30
content: Where there is a dead body, you will find the eagle feeding on the remains (Ezekiel 39:17–19; Matthew 24:28; Luke 17:37).

title: Job 40:1–2
content: The ancient Greek Old Testament (Septuagint) does not include the end of God's first speech.

title: Job 40:3–5
content: Job's short and humble reply does not admit guilt, but it does admit how "insignificant" he is (40:4). Earlier, he believed he could approach God like a prince or even question him (31:37; 13:22–23).

title: Job 40:4
content:
• I am insignificant (compare 42:6): Job was not asking God to forgive his sin. Like Abraham, he recognized that he was not worthy (Genesis 18:27).

  • Job had asked those comforting him to cover their mouths to show shock (21:5). Here, he does so himself in reaction to his own inappropriate words.

title: Job 40:5
content: I have nothing to add: He had no more accusations against God and would not argue again.

title: Job 40:6–7
content: The LORD repeated his earlier challenge (refer to 38:1–3).

title: Job 40:8
content: Job's words had angered Elihu (10:7; 27:2; 31:35–37; 32:2; 34:5). Now, God himself challenged Job's words.

title: Job 40:11–12
content: Job could not humble proud people without God's authority (Isaiah 2:11–12, 17; James 4:6; 1 Peter 5:5–6; Malachi 4:3; Romans 16:20).

title: Job 40:15–24
content:
• After listing natural animals, God described Behemoth and "Leviathan" as creatures humans cannot control (39:1–30; 40:15–24; 41:1–34). Job could not control the wild donkey or ox (39:5–12; 40:15–24). However, God created and could control them, and Job had to accept this fact (41:2).

  • Here, Behemoth appears to be a natural creature:

  1. It is an animal God made, just as he made Job (40:15).

  2. It is not a fierce predator but eats grass like an ox (40:15).

  3. It is in a poem about God’s creation of the natural world, not in a myth about the world's formation. Most commentators think Behemoth is the hippopotamus, a large, grass-eating animal (40:15–19). It rests in the river among lotus plants and reeds (40:21). Like the wild ox, Behemoth is strong (40:16–18, 24; 39:11). Yet it is mostly peaceful (40:20–23).

title: Job 41:1
content:
Unlike the peaceful Behemoth (Job 40:15–24), Leviathan was a threat (see also Job 3:8; Psalms 74:14; 104:26; Isaiah 27:1). Most scholars think Leviathan was like a crocodile, with its powerful jaws and tough skin twisting and turning in the water (Job 41:14; 41:15–17, 23; 41:31–32). But Leviathan is a fire-breathing dragon that wraps around the sun to cause the sun to seem covered (41:18–21; 3:8–9).

The background for Leviathan is the seven-headed sea monster symbolizing chaos in ancient Near Eastern mythology. In the Bible, this wild sea creature often represents chaos and evil, whose head the Lord crushes (Psalm 74:14; Isaiah 27:1; compare Job 9:13; 26:12; Psalm 89:9–10; Isaiah 30:7; 51:9). Later in the Bible, Satan is linked to the ancient serpent and great dragon (Genesis 3; Revelation 12:9; 20:2). Christ and his followers crush his head (Romans 16:20).

title: Job 42:1–6
content: Job understood the message of God’s speeches: I know that You can do all things. Nothing is too hard for him (Genesis 18:14; Jeremiah 32:17; Matthew 19:26). Job says, No plan of Yours can be thwarted (Job 23:13; Isaiah 14:27; 46:10). Job realized how different he was from God.

title: Job 42:5
content: now my eyes have seen You: Before this, Job had not seen God (see 23:8). Now, like the prophet Isaiah, he has been in God's presence and feels overwhelmed by how holy God is (Isaiah 6:1).

title: Job 42:7
content:
• Eliphaz the Temanite was the spokesperson for the friends, probably because of he was older. Eliphaz had a false claim that his advice came from visions of prophecy (4:12–16). Now God spoke to him, but not to support his message.

  • Unlike his three friends, Job spoke accurately about God (compare 13:7–10). Job’s direct questions were more effective in finding out the truth about God than the friends’ shallow definitions of doctrine.

title: Job 42:8–9
content:
• The LORD made Job the "mediator" that Job had hoped to find for himself and that Elihu wanted to be (9:33; 16:19–21; 19:25; 32:1–37:24).

  • go to My servant Job: God wanted Job’s friends to make peace with Job before they offered their gifts (Matthew 5:23–24).

  • My servant Job will pray for you: He had also prayed for his children (1:5; compare James 5:16; 1 John 5:16).

  • When the LORD accepted Job’s prayer, it ironically fulfilled Eliphaz’s promise (Job 22:26–30).

title: Job 42:10
content: Job's fortunes probably included his health (42:16–17). God created humans to bless them, not to do them harm (curse).

title: Job 42:11
content:
• Even though God restored Job, he still needed comfort for the loss of his children. His family and former friends continued to support him, following Job's earlier practices, taking over where the three friends had stopped (4:4; 16:5; 2:11; compare 2 Corinthians 7:6).

  • The money given to Job was not just charity to increase his wealth again. It was also to honor him and gain favor from an influential man (for example, Proverbs 18:16). It might also have been to ease any lack of favor (for example, Genesis 32:20; 33:10; 43:11; 1 Samuel 25:27).

  • Women wore a gold ring in their nose (Genesis 24:47; Proverbs 11:22; Isaiah 3:21). Both men and women wore them on the ears (Genesis 35:4; Exodus 32:2–3; Judges 8:24).

title: Job 42:12
content: When God blessed Job, it ironically fulfilled Bildad’s promise (8:7).

title: Job 42:14
content:
• The names of Job’s new daughters reflect his good fortune God had renewed:

  • Jemimah means “dove” (see Song 2:14).

  • Keziah means “cassia” or “cinnamon flower” (see Psalm 45:8).

  • Keren-happuch means “horn of antimony,” which is a shiny container for make-up.

title: Job 42:15
content: their father granted them an inheritance among their brothers: Daughters usually inherited only if there were no male children (Numbers 27; 36). Perhaps Job's unusual action indicated his great wealth. Only a rich man could give some wealth to the families into which his daughters would marry.

title: Job 42:16
content:
• Job lived for 140 more years, which was about twice as long as a normal life (Psalm 90:10). If God gave him double what he had before (Job 42:10), Job may have already been 70 years old, making his total life 210 years. This would fit the time of the early patriarchs in the Bible (see Genesis 25:7; 35:28; 47:28; 50:26; Deuteronomy 34:7; Joshua 24:29).

  • to the fourth generation: God blessed Job by letting him live long enough to see his children, grandchildren, great-grandchildren, and great-great-grandchildren grow up (Genesis 50:23; Psalm 128:6).

title: Job 42:17
content:
• The patriarchs ("first fathers") Abraham and Isaac also died at an old age (Genesis 25:8; 35:29). Job too lived a long, full life. This fulfilled Eliphaz’s promise (Job 5:26). His promise had its basis on God's general promise (Deuteronomy 6:2; Psalm 91:16).

  • At the end of the book, the ancient Greek Old Testament (Septuagint) adds a note saying that Job will resurrect from the dead at the final resurrection. It also provides information about where and when Job and those who descended from him lived.
